author: BhimDigital
body:
The source is [chaiwithpabrai.com](https://chaiwithpabrai.com). Pabrai chose Stewart.  The uncertainty in Stewart was that it had a $500M debt which was due in about 2 years and there were multiple possible ways how things could have unfolded for Stewart. However, none of the multiple ways were not seemingly as risky. You can have a quick look at Pabrai's reasoning here: [https://bit.ly/3tPfnz2](https://bit.ly/3tPfnz2)  


For ADP, uncertainty in capturing a higher market share can as well be termed as risk (as Pabrai mentions in the link above). The fine line between risk and uncertainty :)

author: E-garr
body:
Yes. I have to do a sep DD on that bc the short seller produced articles out there claim unlimited risk. 

Here is the gunvor contract. Vitol has same language. Shell formula is slightly diff but it has the minimum as well. 

https://ir.tellurianinc.com/all-sec-filings/content/0001104659-21-072704/tm2117591d1_ex10-1.htm

Page 57 of contract

SPA formula is below. (***) is redacted. So the contract calls for the greater of A) a redacted percentage of ttf/jkm OR B) a redacted price per mmbtu in USD terms (One would assume that redacted amount is above cost). Critical language for banks and financing. Ill write up a DD when i have time!


********************copy and paste from contract below**************


9.1.1	Except as otherwise provided pursuant to Section ‎14.3.4, and subject to Section ‎9.1.2, the contract sales price (“CSP”) (expressed in USD per MMBtu rounded to two decimal places) for all LNG made available by Seller to Buyer under this Agreement shall be as follows:
 
CSP = ([***]% JKM CSP) + ([***]%TTF CSP)
 
where:
 
JKM CSP = greater of (a) [***]% JKM – US$[***]/MMBtu and (b) US$[***]/MMBtu
 
where:
 
“JKM” means an amount expressed in USD per MMBtu equal to the arithmetic average of all the JKM (M) frontline quotations published in the “DES Japan/Korea Marker (JKM)” price table for each Platts Business Day, as published in Platts LNG Daily in the “DES Japan/Korea Marker (JKM)” price table, during the Assessment Period;
 
where:
 
“Assessment Period” means the period covering the second half (sixteenth (16th) – month end (unless the sixteenth (16th) is not a Platts Business Day, in which case the next Platts Business Day until month end)) of M-2 month and the first half (first (1st) – fifteenth (15th) (unless the fifteenth (15th) of that month is not a Platts Business Day, in which case the first half will end on the day immediately before the next Platts Business Day)) of M-1 month;
 
“M” means the calendar month following the month in which the Delivery Window of the relevant cargo is scheduled in the ADP to begin;
 
“Platts Business Day” means a Day in respect of which Platts LNG Daily published prices for “DES Japan/Korea Marker (JKM)”; and
 
“Platts LNG Daily” means the publication of that same name published by S&P Global, a division of S&P Global Inc.; and
 
TTF CSP = greater of (a) [***]% TTF – US$[***]/MMBtu and (b) US$[***]/MMBtu

where:
 
“TTF” means the arithmetic average of the daily settlement prices expressed in EUR per MWh of the ICE Dutch Natural Gas TTF Futures Contract for delivery in the Pricing Month on all days for which such contract is the Front Month Contract on the ICE website (www.theice.com), as each daily settlement price is converted to US$/MMBtu using the following formula:

 
 
US$/MMBtu = (EUR/MWh) x CR/3.41214
 
where:
 
“ICE” means InterContinental Exchange;
 
“CR” means, on each Pricing Date, the USD/EUR spot exchange rate published by the European Central Bank and if, on any Pricing Date, the European Central Bank does not publish the USD/EUR spot exchange rate, the USD/EUR spot exchange rate that was published by the European Central Bank on the date immediately prior to such Pricing Date;
 
“Front Month Contract” means, on each Pricing Date, the ICE Dutch Natural Gas TTF Futures Contract that is traded on such Pricing Date with the earliest expiration date;
 
“Pricing Date” means any day on which the ICE Dutch Natural Gas TTF Futures Contract has a settlement price; and
 
“Pricing Month” means the calendar month in which the Delivery Window of the relevant cargo is scheduled in the ADP to begin.

author: Hani95
body:
So I'm actually going to do some market analysis on the direction of the market, and I'd like thoughts and a discussion if possible. Think Socratic discussion. 

In the U.S. I think that the markets are going to soon start a rotation to value, and you can sort of see it starting to occur as bond yields have started to rise, meaning that growth stocks will start to become less attractive relative to value stocks. You've been seeing supply chain and logistics companies like Matson, Maersk, Zim, and other assorted shipping stocks boom during this time period. Commodities stocks in the aluminum sector are poised to outperform, because Guyana just had a coup, and it's a huge exporter of aluminum... Especially to China. With that said, steel and iron ore are the same with exports to China from Australia of iron ore outperforming despite negative relations between these two nations. Both of these types of stocks have outperformed year-to-date, and will continue to do so for the next month or two as forward looking investors look at commentary stating that supply chain, and commodity prices will be elevated well into next week. Finally, home builders have outperformed, and are poised to continue their outperformance due to a massive shortage of homes that will take years to a decade to fix.

I believe in the latter months, in 2022, and heading into 2023 financials will outperform as yields for the 10 year T note rise. First, domestic debit and credit card transaction volume will rise (which bank CEO's , and Visa's CEO, have noted has already started to happen), and this will be followed by international travel spend (Which is very lucrative). This will primarily help Visa, and Mastercard as they have been essentially flat year to date and on a yearly basis. It will also help American Express, and Discover Financial to a lesser extent. Then, credit card balances will grow and forward looking investors will start looking at interest rate hikes by the FED in late 2022-2023, which is the one-two punch that bank stocks will need to see outsize profitability. The strong M&A activity, even in the face of anti-trust scrutiny, is also helping banks. Third, ADP and other benefit provider/payroll companies will do well as payrolls continue to increase, and unemployment continues to go down. The runway is still clear there. Then, there are the mortgage companies where there currently has been a pricing war which should cool sometime in early 2022, allowing for Gain on Sale margins to normalize to roughly 115-185BPS, while the value of their Mortgage servicing rights should increase alongside the yield for the 10YR T notes. Open banking should continue its outperformance, with strong markets in Asia, the Middle East, Europe, and Latin and South America, and growing adoption in North America. Companies like Paysafe, PAG, Razer, etcetera should do well in this environment. Finally, the moratorium on school loan payments should cease very soon allowing companies like Navient and Sofi to regain momentum.

I also believe that airlines will start to outperform starting in Q1-Q2 2022, as flight restrictions start falling away, and business travel starts to resume at a more normal tempo. Personally, Delta Airlines and the budget airlines are my preferred ones. Then, there are homebuilders who will continue their outperformance as they have significantly deleveraged and still have long runways for price to earnings growth. I'd expect dividend increases in the latter half of 2022 to reflect this. Third is General Electric under Larry Culp, who's turnaround efforts haven't recently been noticed, but who's conducted strong execution. From their wind turbines, to their jet engines, to their medical division, there is strong growth to be had and I believe we'll see a spurt in the share price to reflect the reality of 2022 and Culp's momentous turn around. I also believe chip fabricators (and chip designers) will outperform. TSM has been relatively flat in the last 3 months, save for a one week burst of over 5% to reflect the fact that they're increasing prices across the board from 10 to 20%. Intel, meanwhile, is building a chip fabrication plant in Ireland which will be entirely dedicated to vehicle chip manufacturing, which I think will be a success. Finally, I believe the used car (autonation), and new car companies such as Ford and GM as well as Volkswagen will outperform in 2022 due to the scarcity of vehicles, compounded by Hurricane Ida's destruction of numerous vehicles (And the risk that other natural disasters destroy even more vehicles).

The China rally, meanwhile, is unsustainable in the light of the regulatory tempo on the free market principle that China ever so briefly embraced. In light of all these actions, it is my firm belief that  China is, or will, embrace capitalism "with chinese characteristics." The crackdowns are far from over, and I believe the state will go further in the realm of entertainment and video streaming, such as suspending screen time for minors on video streaming platforms (something they already do) to a level consistent to where they've placed video gaming limits to combat the myopia epidemic as well as fan culture. They are also likely to crackdown on drinking establishments, and liquor companies to crack down on the excessive drinking in China, in an attempt to stave off chronic health conditions that could accrue, as well as crack down on companies trying to profiteer off a rapidly aging China. These are just a few sectors where I see potential intervention, but there are likely others. The fact that systematic debt has reached such dizzying levels in China is also worrying, and presents a structural issue. A house of cards, if you will. The fact that JD bought an insignificant sum of shares, means that there is a rally in tech stock shares today is foolish, especially since it's broad based and not tailored means there's no solid shoring. Furthermore, the debt to equity levels for some companies, such as Iqiyi, Evergrande, and other stocks is extremely worrying.

I believe emerging market stocks in Brazil, Mexico, India, the Middle East, and Turkey present better opportunities.

body:
I'm levered 1.5 from UVXY and another 3 times from OTM calls. 

Sell before close! Jobs report is *before* market open at 8:30, so calls/puts will be locked in.

ADP telegraphing weak report, so short tech at your own risk, but I'll probably get some SVXY calls at the peak tmrw for the stabilization Fri. Second leg will be risky if the market assumes tapering and starts to price it in.

Exciting gamble.

author: wookie767
body:
In case reddit links are not allowed, here's the text: I'm taking a bullish take on $SPY on Daily chart. Volume POC is at 435, based on September only; SPY is within 100MA support; it's outside of Linear Regression (which is 1 STDev). We're beginning 4th Qtr, so institutions will likely be looking for great stocks to buy. There are also potential bullish reports coming next week (ISM PMI; ADP Employment; Unemployment rate).   
This is a minority take on SPY in light of all the negativity on TV and fintwit FURU's.

  
I'll be looking for Nov 1 450C, which (off market) is 90cents/contract.

author: SofaKingStonked
body:
In order of expected returns;

Himx - their qoq growth numbers look like some companies yoy numbers. They do various things but mostly known for display ic’s. (I want to mention micron in this same breath but momentum seems against it so I’m more aggressively pursuing himx)

Indi - automotive infotainment asic semi company (also does other things but all automotive focused). Huge tier 1 backlog

Mrvl - my preferred 5G play

Amd - I’m investing in cloud in multiple ways and see a lot of growth for Amd in server

Amat - earlier in the year I would have had asml above Amat as my top semi equipment company but they’ve run really hard and fast ytd so I feel Amat is a better value with lrcx a close second.

Cree I like for their rf products and SiC wafer technology but my small position is not growing until they drop the led business officially.

author: smokeyjay
body:
I own LRCX.  Most recent added more at 600.  Sold off my TSM to consolidate my stock portfolio.

I think AMAT & KLAC are also good buys.  ASML is a good company but richly valued imo.

Honestly a sector ETF might work for most ppl.  These are long term holds and not really WSB material.  I don't know how I feel about any positive short term trends - the whole world knows about chip shortages.

author: Swingtrader79
body: Don't buy the ETFs. Most are manufacturers that have reached capacity. That means they now need to spend a lot more money on new equipment to enable them to make more chips. That will weigh on earnings (unless they capitalize the expense), but in either case, they have less cash flow. The real winners in the next year or two are the companies selling these makers the equipment to expand their plants. That's ASML and AMAT. I've got AMAT. I failed to buy ASML foolishly but am waiting for a pullback to get into it. I also recently bought INDI b/c the smaller semis are suddenly getting more business with the big ones over capacity.

author: puregoblinvomit
body: Yes! LRCX and AMAT have a huge growing business in their legacy 150nm and above semi equipment groups (what AMAT calls ICAPs) these are the chips that auto makers and tons of other companies are missing right now. The semi equipment makers will be the winners in the end as fabs and foundries are all localized around the globe!

author: apophisdagod
body: Can't go wrong with AMAT or LRCX they both make chip making machines along with touch screen machines etc. I work for a company that supplies both of them and we can't keep up with the orders. AMAT actually offered to buy the company to just make parts for them. So naturally I am in AMAT.

author: yakadayaka
body:
"people that really have no business speculating on stocks"

For far too long investing in the stock market has been the domain of the wealthy elite. The premise for this is predicated by capitalism, of course. The ordinary folk are expected to spend every penny they earn or can borrow so that the companies the wealthy are invested in can rake in massive profits. 

The tide is slowly turning, and more and more people, particularly the younger folk, have begun to learn the ropes of investing. And are happy to do it by themselves using low cost funds rather than through an intermediary (aka financial advisor) and high cost mutual funds. If you visited Fidelity Canada's website just 10 years ago you would have noticed that it was pitched toward investment advisors - and how they can help their clients. Not so any more - and it's the same with other companies like Vanguard as well. 

The new investors stepped into the market in March last year because they had learned to recognize value. Stocks, in spite of the risks of Covid, were ridiculously cheap. They stepped in and set the floor on a market that traders would have happily shorted until it went even lower. 

So yes, the shoe shine boys are now becoming savvy investors. What would be interesting to see is how such a democratization of investing would impact corporate bottom lines in 15 - 20 years. After all, Zeus help us all if the people who are supposed to borrow and spend suddenly start saving and investing.

author: MaintenanceCall
body:
There have been a couple discussions on this subject on this sub and others, I'd suggest doing a search about the tax implications of covered calls. Fidelity has a introductory article on the subject which is helpful as well. *: A keyword you might want to look up is "holding period". Selling contracts on stock affects the holding periods.    
  
The two big things I'd note is that:   
1. Collecting premium is a taxable event.   
2. Selling "unqualified" options contracts can create taxable events as well. Generally, selling in the money covered calls is effectively selling the stock (since it's likely to be executed) so the IRS treats it as selling the stock. This means that the capital gains rate is whatever it would be for the stock the day you open the contract. 
  
The devil is in the details of course, but essentially, be aware that selling in the money calls on stock you've owned less than a year is likely to be taxed as short term capital gains. 
  
Out of the money contracts and stock you've held longer than a year pretty much avoids these issues though.

author: LiqCourage
body:
You may not think you are good at math but you have a better handle on your current financial picture than most people your age.  This is good!  give yourself a pat on the back.

I didn't note any mention of an emergency fund.  This should be cash that can be used to cover your living expenses fully for 3-6 months if something really goes wrong.  if you don't have that, start prioritizing cash flow to build that up.

And yes, maximize your retirement benefit plans.  On the 403b, make sure you are getting the maximum match.  I can't tell for sure from the way you have described it, but if you are missing any % on the match, that is free money that you should prioritize getting (some employers match the first x% of your salary... if that is 10% in this case you should increase your contribution to 10%).  On a cash flow basis if you have to pick between getting the maximum match in 403b over maxing out Roth IRA, get the 403b match first, then try to max the Roth.  Prioritize those two goals above money you put into taxable investing.

IMO, Fidelity was the right choice of the two providers you mentioned, as you can build a wider relationship with them over time and they have a lot of other financial options.  Set up your brokerage account with them if you haven't already.  You did mention VTSAX so maybe you already have a set up with Vanguard.

regarding funds: at your age capital appreciation is the best goal.  keep it simple and manageable.  I would pick the Fid 500 as large cap is the right strategy at this stage of the bull market and at your age and investment horizon.  The other fund is target age fund (typically a fund that holds other Fidelity funds and changes allocation over time along with your expected retirement age).  This will be better during a down market for sure than the other, but I don't see one of those for a while.  So pay attention and plan to change allocation when a bear market comes along.

Keeping it simple makes things easier to manage, while you grow your understanding of investing.  Best wishes!

author: Codesandstuff
body:
So when you are selling a call you are doing just that, writing an option that you sell to a counterparty. This means you are short this call your counterparty can exercise the call which forces you to sell this counterparty 100 shares (per call) at the designated strike price.

What it sounds like you are describing is Covered Calls and Naked Calls. Covered simply means you already own 100 shares, so you sell what you already own. Naked means when assigned you have to go onto the open market, buy 100 shares at the current price, and sell them to your counterparty at the strike price.

What this means functionally is if you are not covered you are subject to theoretically infinite loss because there is no ceiling to what price a stock could get to.

A basic example: You sell a call at a strike of 10 but do not own the stock. If the option is exercised and the stock price is 100? You must go out and buy 100 shares at 100/sh and sell them at 10/sh, incurring a loss of 90/sh.

Being "Covered" is represented differently on different brokers. I use Fidelity and they also do not explicitly say whether my covered calls are covered or not.

Another notable difference is you should not be able to open naked calls if you are not approved for the proper level of options (level 4). Same with covered calls but they require a looser level (level 1).

edit: [Here's](https://www.investopedia.com/ask/answers/032615/what-difference-between-covered-call-and-regular-call.asp#:~:text=An%20investor%20in%20a%20naked,generates%20income%20for%20the%20investor) a good source that probably describes this better :)

author: throwawayinvestacct
body:
> Would it be a correct statement that if my overall portfolio consistently shows higher gains than the S&P and/or VTI, then I’m “beating the market”? . . . And, conversely, if my portfolio consistently has lower gains than those indexes, I’m better off just putting everything into the index instead?

No, because of the point you recognized with your next example:

>A more specific example: let’s say (hypothetically) my portfolio is like 70% tech stocks, should I be comparing my performance to QQQ? It makes sense in my mind, just want to make sure my logic is correct.

That is probably a closer analogue, yes. 

The reason QQQ is the better benchmark (and why beating the S&P with such a profile wouldn't necessarily be "beating the market") is you've bought a riskier portfolio, so *should* see greater returns as a result. "Beating the market" tends to be discussed in terms of *risk-adjusted* returns. 

If you have a portfolio that is much riskier than the S&P and outperform it by 1%, you haven't "beaten" the S&P, you haven't generated any [alpha](https://www.investopedia.com/terms/a/alpha.asp) as an investor, you've just added risk. As with your QQQ example, if you just want that added risk, you could just buy QQQ instead of S&P to get that added risk without your stockpicking.

>I use Fidelity, and the performance page says (I think) that my personal return over the last 3 months is 36% higher than the return of S&P, but I’m not sure if I’m reading it right or if that metric is useful at all.

The other thing to remember is that short-term overperformance is no guarantee of *long-term* overperformance. Looking to the 2017 year-end SPIVA "scorecard", roughly 40% of US fund managers [managed to beat their benchmark index over one year](https://www.aei.org/carpe-diem/more-evidence-that-its-very-hard-to-beat-the-market-over-time-95-of-financial-professionals-cant-do-it/) (after fees). Heck, a *majority* of mid- and small-cap fund managers did. But, over the *long* haul (3, 5, 10, 15 years) that edge quickly vanished, and the vast majority underperformed their benchmark index.

body:
Yes great long term hold. 

Some people don’t realize companies like PYPL/SQ still utilize V/MA as their payment networks partner. I look at FinTechs more so as partners with V/MA and not competitors. Unless one of these companies wanted to start their own payment network directly. 

BNPL (like Affirm) could take some of the credit card business but I wouldn’t be surprised if some companies could start letting you even make installment payments via CC instead of direct ACH. I’m sure people even use their debit cards, which are V/MA branded

My biggest concern is more regulation around payment networks and potential allowance of smaller networks to gain a piece of the pie. I read an article the other day how Australia may mandate low-cost debit card system for payments, which would allow banks to potentially utilize cheaper payment networks as opposed to V/MA (which are more expensive). I’m still not overly concerned with this yet to make me back off my stance that both V/MA are great long term holds, but something to watch. 

Once international travel comes back some post COVID, V/MA will shoot up as this is their bread and butter. That segment has still not really recovered yet from COVID and will be one of the last things that does.

author: firststrike001
body:
V & MA dont have any credit risk associated with them. Banks lend money, people use this money to buy stuff. 
V & MA process this transaction and pocket some change.
PayPal, Zelle etc either not provide credit and work only with debit ( cash thay you already have in bank account). This model of payment is popular in India & China l, but in US most people prefer credit cards as it offers insurance, fraud protection and many other benefits.

So if they start providing credit, they will have tons of customer debt on their balance sheet, much like a bank.

So IMHO V & MA are much better plays than the rest of above mentioned Fintech ones.



As to why they are down right now, a large part of revenue comes from foreign transactions (Tourism) and that is being hit even more by covid mutants.

author: Summebride
body:
Generally not.  Visa and MasterCard don't sell to or deal with cardholders.  Their customers are vendors (store merchants) and franchisees.  The franchisees pay for the privilege of operating a visa franchise.  The franchisee (like your local savings and loan, or chase or capital one, etc) uses the visa name and network, but they own the loan.  That's the whole business.  Hometown Bank Ltd pays Visa so they can have a Hometown Visa card, and they hope that all the cardholder debt earns them profit that exceeds what they have to pay Visa.  

So in the BNPL model, the debt is structured differently.  The hope is to make money on the "pay later" aspect, with fees or charges or interest.  It's sort of competitive to Visa/MasterCard's way of lending.

author: Last_Man_0n_Earth
body:
First of emergency funds are called are not suppose to have risk associated with it that's why they are emergency funds. But if insist on protecting the money against inflation then you are looking at the wrong asset class. You should be looking at bonds which have a safer risk specifically TIPS(treasury inflation protected securities). 

If you are unfamiliar with bonds here is a quick break down. Bonds pay coupon payments a percentage of the par or principle value of the bond. E.g a bond sells for 1000$ and has a coupon rate of 3%. You get 30$ every year until the maturity of the bond. They are usually semi-annual so you get paid 15 every 6 months.  Yield to maturity is the estimated yield you would get if the bond is held to maturity. At maturity you collect the face value of the bond. Say you held the bond had a maturity of 2 years then you get your 1000 back plus 60 from your coupon payments.

Bonds have 2 major components of risk principal and interest risk. This can get complicated but all you need to know is if interest rates go up bond price go down and vice verse.(if you want me to explain I can, just let me know) There are ma y different types of bonds and not all have the same risk.

How does TIPS solve your problem? 
Well as the name suggest TIPS moves with inflation. If inflation rises by 3%. Then the principle value increases by 3% as well as your coupon payments. If there deflation the principle value decrease as well as coupon payments. E.g from the previous example your bond will be worth 1030$ and coupon payments would be 30.9$ annually.

&#x200B;

Consumers will be able to instantly withdraw and move money from their PayPal and Venmo accounts to their bank account via their Visa debit cards leveraging Visa Direct—providing an experience that offers speed, security and convenience.  
  
Enhanced data quality:  
PayPal will ensure that data provided to issuers and their cardholders for Visa-funded transactions will be consistent with the information that is received with traditional Visa card transactions. This will ensure a better consumer experience, reduce cardholder confusion, ensure proper application of rewards and reduce costly and time-consuming disputes.  
  
Economic incentives:  
The agreement affords PayPal certain economic incentives, including Visa incentives for increased volume, and greater long-term Visa fee certainty.  
  
“Giving consumers choice in how and where they pay is essential to our goal of being a customer champion and we welcome the opportunity to work with more partners like Visa who share our vision,” said Dan Schulman, president and chief executive officer, PayPal. “This agreement opens new avenues for PayPal to collaborate with Visa, financial institutions and others in the payments ecosystem to deliver greater value, more choice and new experiences for our joint customers wherever they transact online, in app or in store.”  
  
“We are excited to begin a new chapter with PayPal. Our agreement provides a framework for our companies to work together collaboratively,” said Charlie Scharf, chief executive officer, Visa. “PayPal has built industry-leading capabilities that complement those of Visa and our clients, and working together, we will be able to deliver better solutions for consumers and merchants. At Visa, we are focused on growth by providing our issuer and acquirer clients—and their clients, merchants and consumers—with the best way to pay and be paid everywhere and this agreement supports this approach.”

author: ricke813
body:
Just going to copy & paste my comment from another V post that also applies to MA:

I was a former V investor, made a solid return, and regretted it because there were more innovative fintechs I could have invested in like OP mentioned.

Definitely agree the TAM is huge because by definition it's all the money in the world, but I'm sure there are other stocks that can give you better stock price appreciation taking advantage of the short-term trends.

Also something not a lot of retail & Wall Street investors talk about is how V and also MA's business model is overindexed on travel relative to other fintechs since those transactions are higher yielding & margin given the FX. My #1 reason for selling was because I see personal traveling slowly returning while business traveling is impaired for the long-term after lessons from the pandemic with Zoom. V claims they rely more on personal travel, but never quantified it and it was just a red flag for me.

Overall solid stock, but there are better opportunities out there.

author: I_know_nothing_42
body:
MU's earnings are in 24 days. 

Expect vol to increase, place the trade then. If bearish sell the call spreads. It already took a hit in early august for supply issues. Selling the call spread is a little bit easier to predict what you'll make. If you buy a put spread, the vol collapse and the spread having to go fully ITM to realize a full gain has more variables at work. You can buy the put spread and still lose even with having the direction right.

Working myself out of a put that is ITM right now.

I'm looking to get out next week and waiting until earnings to put new positions on.  

I wouldn't be betting against MU just because spot prices are falling. That means supply chains are working their way out and that they will be producing at capacity vs charging a little bit more per diminished output. They can actually make more money overall at lower prices. This will be a quicker price recovery than the 2011 Fukushima earthquake. Demand is not going away.

author: MightyManorMan
body:
The point of markets is to always push the top of the index up. If you are waiting for it to go down, you might be waiting a long long long time. 

Look at Paypal, pretty close to value. Company is still growing, maybe 15% a year or so. EPS is up. Sitting on cash.

Look at Apple, pretty close to value. Company still growing, maybe 5% a year or so. EPS is up. Sitting on cash. And buying back their shares if they go too low... bought back about 790 million shares in 2020.

Microsoft, a little over values, growing revenue, growing earnings, sitting on cash. And buying back their shares if they go too low... bought back about 50 million shares in 2020.

There is plenty of value.

author: not_creative1
body:
As someone who works in this industry in silicon valley, main problem Intel has is talent. 

Intel has hemorrhaged talent to Apple, AMD, Nvidia over the last 5 years. Intel is no where near competitive in pay compared to those companies and are losing people left and right. I know several of my friends who left Intel for companies like Apple, qualcomm and so on.

Intel needs a revival from the ground up. Intel has a massive layer of middle managers who dont do much but have been around for 10+ years and do not plan on moving. But the young talented engineers, who are the actual foot soldiers who work on the products are leaving in droves.


Intel needs a complete overhaul of its culture, management and compensation structure. I dont know if they can do that in time.

author: beefstake
body:
Less bad then you might think. Most people fundamentally misunderstand what caused the supply crunch thus fundamentally misunderstand who is adversely affected.

Covid didn't suddenly cause a massive spike in demand in order to precipitate a crunch. There was some demand increase in consumer electronics sector as more people purchased equipement to work from home but this is rather minimal and mostly focused on products that people didn't already have and are using lower end semiconductor processes, think webcams, mice, keyboards. Take a look at LOGI to see how this side of the demand increase played out.

Now, so what -actually- caused the supply crunch? Well actually it was automakers and other traditional industries that forecasted a massive decrease in demand cancelling or scaling back their supply contracts. This caused foundries to either spin down for retool or sell capacity to someone else. Both are having a significant impact on auto chips right now which are mostly produced on the less advanced 32nm+ node processes.

The latter is why this affects TSLA less (though they are ultimately still affected which I will address later). They went ahead and purchased the depressed capacity, similarly AAPL/GOOG/QCOM/MRVL all took advantage of this to buy up capacity and lock in cheaper rates for the next couple of years while autos and industrial companies were panicking about a sustained economic recession.

However this still ultimately does affect TSLA (and NIO, LI, etc that took similar approaches) in that purchasing capacity during the dip doesn't protect you from increased requirements going forward due to growth. So while they aren't needing to cut production like traditional autos that stupidly cancelled their contracts they aren't able to grow capacity because the same companies that cancelled are now willing to buy capacity at a premium and are buying everything they can.

This has some big follow-on effects for the semi-conductor industry though, especially combined with developments over the last few years w.r.t geopolitics. Firstly all the big foundries (INTC/TSM/Samsung) are building out new fabs now. These take 2-3 years to online but once they do come online we are going to see a massive supply glut which will drastically lower the prices of NAND, consumer electronics chips etc and free up the older fabs for the next gen of auto/industrial chips which will slowly upgrade from 32nm+.

The boom/bust, crunch/glut cycle is nothing new for semi-conductors but there has just been a perfect storm of factors to make this particular cycle very noticable for the first time of people outside of consumer electronics.
